Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language used to develop relationships in formal and informal situations
Elaboration: Recognising that language is adjusted in different contexts, for example, in degree of formality when moving between group discussions and presenting a group report

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language used to develop relationships in formal and informal situations
Elaboration: Understanding how age, expertise and familiarity influence the ways in which people interact, and how these codes and conventions vary across cultures

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language used to develop relationships in formal and informal situations
Elaboration: Recognising the importance of using inclusive language

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language used to develop relationships in formal and informal situations
Elaboration: Exploring cultural respects for first nations australian elders, and greeting conventions between first nations australians

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the subjective language of opinion and feeling and the objective language of factual reporting
Elaboration: Identifying ways thinking verbs are used to express opinions, for example, "i think", "i believe", and ways summary verbs are used to report findings; for example, "we concluded"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling and opportunities to compare subjective and objective language in different contexts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the subjective language of opinion and feeling and the objective language of factual reporting
Elaboration: Comparing statements that have similar information presented objectively and subjectively; for example, "the man has 6 cats.", "the man has too many noisy cats."

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts across the curriculum have different language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages depending on purposes
Elaboration: Identifying the typical stages and language features of texts such as narratives, factual recounts, imaginative recounts, biographies, information reports, explanations, book talks, poetry and arguments for a particular purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts across the curriculum have different language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages depending on purposes
Elaboration: Understanding how and why text structure is important in texts such as sequential and causal explanations, and comparative and part-whole information reports

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts across the curriculum have different language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages depending on purposes
Elaboration: Recognising that poems have different purposes that influence the organisation into characteristic stages, for example, poems that tell stories, poems that describe, and poems that reflect on aspects of life

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how texts across the curriculum have different language features and are typically organised into characteristic stages depending on purposes
Elaboration: Recognising the difference between a text's form, such as a poster, email or list, and its organisation into stages depending on its social purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how text connectives including temporal and conditional words and topic word associations are used to sequence and connect ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how authors construct texts that are cohesive and coherent using pronouns that link to something previously mentioned, and determiners, for example, "this", "that", "these" and "those", to identify things
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •creating and categorising word banks of connectives according to their use, for example clarifying; showing cause/result; indicating time; sequencing ideas; adding information; condition/concession

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how text connectives including temporal and conditional words and topic word associations are used to sequence and connect ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how authors construct texts that are cohesive and coherent using pronouns that link to something previously mentioned, and determiners, for example, "this", "that", "these" and "those", to identify things
EALDElaboration: •opportunities to identify and explain use of connectives when reading texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how text connectives including temporal and conditional words and topic word associations are used to sequence and connect ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how authors use text connectives to create links between sentences, for example, "however", "therefore", "nevertheless" and "in addition"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify how text connectives including temporal and conditional words and topic word associations are used to sequence and connect ideas
Elaboration: Recognising how text connectives link sections of a text, providing sequences through time, for example, "firstly", "then", "next" and "finally"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify text navigation features of online texts that enhance readability including headlines drop-down menus links graphics and layout
Elaboration: Investigating the features used for texts such as headings and subheadings in print text, home pages and subpages in digital texts, and how these help the reader select text for a purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify text navigation features of online texts that enhance readability including headlines drop-down menus links graphics and layout
Elaboration: Comparing the features of texts on similar topics online

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that complex sentences contain one independent clause and at least one dependent clause typically joined by a subordinating conjunction to create relationships such as time and causality
Elaboration: Creating richer, more specific descriptions by using adjectival clauses, for example, "crossing the mountain range was difficult." becomes "the mountain pass, which had received days of heavy rain, was dangerous."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to build sentences from sentence stems and from reconstructing cut-up sentences

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that complex sentences contain one independent clause and at least one dependent clause typically joined by a subordinating conjunction to create relationships such as time and causality
Elaboration: Creating richer, more specific descriptions by using adjectival clauses, for example, "crossing the mountain range was difficult." becomes "the mountain pass, which had received days of heavy rain, was dangerous."
EALDElaboration: •opportunities to build or deconstruct sentences from clause cards

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that complex sentences contain one independent clause and at least one dependent clause typically joined by a subordinating conjunction to create relationships such as time and causality
Elaboration: Creating more precise and detailed sentences by adding adverbial clauses, for example, "they crossed the mountain range." becomes "although the path was overgrown, they crossed the mountain range."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Investigate how quoted (direct) and reported (indirect) speech are used
Elaboration: Investigating examples of quoted (direct) speech; for example, "he said 'i'll go to the park today.'", and reported (indirect) speech; for example, "he told me he was going to the park today.", and why they have been used in different contexts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how adverb groups/phrases and prepositional phrases work in different ways to provide circumstantial details about an activity
Elaboration: Investigating in texts how adverb groups/phrases and prepositional phrases can provide details of the circumstances surrounding a happening or state, for example, "at midnight (time) he rose slowly (manner) from the chair (place) and went upstairs (place)."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to manipulate different types of phrases, within sentences; for example ‘Kritha went on the bus, to the beach’. ‘Kitha went to the beach on the bus.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand past present and future tenses and their impact on meaning in a sentence
Elaboration: Understanding the tense that types of texts are commonly written in; for example, informative texts are usually written in present tense
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •examples from shared texts of how tense is used and its effect on meaning

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand past present and future tenses and their impact on meaning in a sentence
Elaboration: Identifying the tense in texts they read

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Explore the effect of choices when framing an image placement of elements in the image and salience on composition of still and moving images in texts
Elaboration: Examining visual and multimodal texts, building a vocabulary to describe visual elements and techniques such as framing, composition and salience, and beginning to understand how these choices influence viewer response
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of images that they have familiarity with or reflect the diversity of students in the class

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Explore the effect of choices when framing an image placement of elements in the image and salience on composition of still and moving images in texts
Elaboration: Examining visual and multimodal texts, building a vocabulary to describe visual elements and techniques such as framing, composition and salience, and beginning to understand how these choices influence viewer response
EALDElaboration: •development of glossaries and annotated examples of work that make metalinguistic terminology clear.

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Expand vocabulary by exploring a range of synonyms and antonyms and using words encountered in a range of sources
Elaboration: Building vocabulary from research about technical and learning area-specific topics; for example, gravity and magnetic forces
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •being able to use a Thesaurus with careful explanation of meanings and cultural use

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Expand vocabulary by exploring a range of synonyms and antonyms and using words encountered in a range of sources
Elaboration: Building vocabulary from research about technical and learning area-specific topics; for example, gravity and magnetic forces
EALDElaboration: •using word clines to develop understanding of nuanced vocabulary

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Expand vocabulary by exploring a range of synonyms and antonyms and using words encountered in a range of sources
Elaboration: Determining or clarifying the shades of meaning of synonyms and antonyms

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Expand vocabulary by exploring a range of synonyms and antonyms and using words encountered in a range of sources
Elaboration: Using words encountered in texts that are formed from a first nations australian language; for example, woomba woomba or toowoom was the place referred to by first nations australians on the darling downs, and then the name was referred to as toowoomba by the drovers

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that punctuation signals dialogue through quotation marks and that dialogue follows conventions for the use of capital letters commas and boundary punctuation
Elaboration: Identifying the use of quotation marks, capital letters, commas and boundary punctuation to signal dialogue in texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that punctuation signals dialogue through quotation marks and that dialogue follows conventions for the use of capital letters commas and boundary punctuation
Elaboration: Using punctuated dialogue in own writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise similar storylines ideas and relationships in different contexts in literary texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Comparing the plots and characters in 2 literary texts with similar ideas; for example, 2 literary texts that explore friendship in texts by wide-ranging australian authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise similar storylines ideas and relationships in different contexts in literary texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Commenting on how literary texts set in different time periods present ideas about nature

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise similar storylines ideas and relationships in different contexts in literary texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Discussing how everyday life, such as mealtimes and family relationships, is depicted in particular historical and cultural contexts in texts by wide-ranging world authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise similar storylines ideas and relationships in different contexts in literary texts by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors
Elaboration: Recognising similar storylines and ideas in literature by first nations australian authors

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Describe the effects of text structures and language features in literary texts when responding to and sharing opinions
Elaboration: Sharing and discussing understanding of the effects of literary techniques on their appreciation of texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •identifying text structure using culturally appropriate and familiar texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Describe the effects of text structures and language features in literary texts when responding to and sharing opinions
Elaboration: Sharing responses to texts using appropriate language to talk specifically about grammar and literature; for example, "the use of the noun groups to describe the character really helps to create images for the reader."

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Describe the effects of text structures and language features in literary texts when responding to and sharing opinions
Elaboration: Using language appropriate to a text, such as "flashback", "tension" and "resolution", when sharing opinions about plot structure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how authors and illustrators make stories engaging by the way they develop character setting and plot tensions
Elaboration: Examining an author's choice of language to describe a character's appearance, behaviour and speech
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanations and examples of the metalanguage used in examining literature, for example characterisation, plot development

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how authors and illustrators make stories engaging by the way they develop character setting and plot tensions
Elaboration: Discussing what is learnt about a character through dialogue, such as their likes, dislikes or personal qualities

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how authors and illustrators make stories engaging by the way they develop character setting and plot tensions
Elaboration: Identifying moments in the plot where characters are faced with choices, and commenting on how the author makes the reader care about their decisions and the consequences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how authors and illustrators make stories engaging by the way they develop character setting and plot tensions
Elaboration: Identifying how illustrations contribute to the meaning of stories by first nations australian authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine the use of literary devices and deliberate word play in literary texts including poetry to shape meaning
Elaboration: Defining neologisms and puns, and identifying how they are used by authors to create a sense of freshness, originality and playfulness
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •careful attention to explanations of figurative language, idiomatic language and word play as these are often culturally and historically based and rely on understanding of less common vocabulary; for example ‘walking a tightrope’.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine the use of literary devices and deliberate word play in literary texts including poetry to shape meaning
Elaboration: Discussing poetic language, including adjectives that engage readers emotionally and bring the poet's subject matter to life

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Examine the use of literary devices and deliberate word play in literary texts including poetry to shape meaning
Elaboration: Exploring emotive language in texts by first nations australian poets and authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts by developing storylines characters and settings
Elaboration: Creating texts using a range of sentence types, including dialogue and literary devices
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •presenting their texts visually or orally and receiving feedback, before attempting a written text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit literary texts by developing storylines characters and settings
Elaboration: Collaborating with a peer to edit literary texts by sharing feedback about choices made to develop storylines, characters and settings

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare texts from different times with similar purposes and audiences to identify similarities and differences in their depictions of events
Elaboration: Viewing documentaries and news footage from different periods, comparing the purpose and audience; for example, coverage of major sporting events

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Compare texts from different times with similar purposes and audiences to identify similarities and differences in their depictions of events
Elaboration: Comparing the texts used to communicate between family members, noting similarities and differences as a result of changing technology

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen for key points and information to carry out tasks and contribute to discussions acknowledging another opinion linking a response to the topic and sharing and extending ideas and information
Elaboration: Making notes about a task, asking questions to clarify or follow up information, and seeking assistance if required

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen for key points and information to carry out tasks and contribute to discussions acknowledging another opinion linking a response to the topic and sharing and extending ideas and information
Elaboration: Developing speaking and listening behaviours, including acknowledging and extending others' contributions, presenting ideas and opinions clearly and coherently

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the characteristic features used in imaginative informative and persuasive texts to meet the purpose of the text
Elaboration: Identifying how authors use language to create imaginary worlds

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the characteristic features used in imaginative informative and persuasive texts to meet the purpose of the text
Elaboration: Identifying how authors use techniques such as headings, italics and bold text to support readers or viewers to navigate specific texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the characteristic features used in imaginative informative and persuasive texts to meet the purpose of the text
Elaboration: Identifying visual features such as images and layout used in informative texts to complement, add to or shape understanding of a topic

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read different types of texts integrating phonic semantic and grammatical knowledge to read accurately and fluently re-reading and self-correcting when needed
Elaboration: Reading increasingly complex texts using established word identification strategies, knowledge of the topic and understanding of text structure and language features
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •additional scaffolding with new and unfamiliar vocabulary to build field knowledge before the text is read or viewed

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning to expand topic knowledge and ideas and evaluate texts
Elaboration: Making connections between information in print, images and sound

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning to expand topic knowledge and ideas and evaluate texts
Elaboration: Reading or listening for key topic-specific vocabulary words to build understanding

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning to expand topic knowledge and ideas and evaluate texts
Elaboration: Reading or listening to interpret the main idea and supporting ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning to expand topic knowledge and ideas and evaluate texts
Elaboration: Identifying evidence and reasoning used by authors to support points or arguments

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning to expand topic knowledge and ideas and evaluate texts
Elaboration: Applying self-monitoring strategies, such as re-reading, pausing and questioning, and self-correction strategies, such as confirming and cross-checking

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning to expand topic knowledge and ideas and evaluate texts
Elaboration: Connecting the use of colours, images, symbols and patterns in texts by first nations australian authors and illustrators

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising predicting connecting summarising monitoring and questioning to build literal and inferred meaning to expand topic knowledge and ideas and evaluate texts
Elaboration: Evaluating an author's use of evidence to support arguments

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal imaginative informative and persuasive texts using visual features relevant linked ideas complex sentences appropriate tense synonyms and antonyms correct spelling of multisyllabic words and simple punctuation
Elaboration: Using research to gather ideas for writing, and integrating information from a range of sources, which may include those found online
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to jointly construct texts with teacher support

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal imaginative informative and persuasive texts using visual features relevant linked ideas complex sentences appropriate tense synonyms and antonyms correct spelling of multisyllabic words and simple punctuation
Elaboration: Using research to gather ideas for writing, and integrating information from a range of sources, which may include those found online
EALDElaboration: •more comprehensive scaffolds to guide organising the text and choices of vocabulary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal imaginative informative and persuasive texts using visual features relevant linked ideas complex sentences appropriate tense synonyms and antonyms correct spelling of multisyllabic words and simple punctuation
Elaboration: Selecting text structure and planning how to group ideas into paragraphs to sequence content

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal imaginative informative and persuasive texts using visual features relevant linked ideas complex sentences appropriate tense synonyms and antonyms correct spelling of multisyllabic words and simple punctuation
Elaboration: Using topic-specific, precise and varied vocabulary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal imaginative informative and persuasive texts using visual features relevant linked ideas complex sentences appropriate tense synonyms and antonyms correct spelling of multisyllabic words and simple punctuation
Elaboration: Using grammatical features, including different types of verb groups, noun groups and adverb groups/phrases, for effective descriptions and details according to purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create edit and publish written and multimodal imaginative informative and persuasive texts using visual features relevant linked ideas complex sentences appropriate tense synonyms and antonyms correct spelling of multisyllabic words and simple punctuation
Elaboration: Revising written texts to improve the selection of words used to connect ideas and improve the cohesion of the text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver structured oral and/or multimodal presentations to report on a topic tell a story recount events or present an argument using subjective and objective language complex sentences visual features tone pace pitch and volume
Elaboration: Reporting on a topic in an organised manner, providing relevant facts and descriptive detail to support audience understanding, and using references to reliable sources to support claims
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to view videos of presentations, which can be deconstructed to model and highlight how particular features of the presentation make it successful; for example the pace and tone of the delivery

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver structured oral and/or multimodal presentations to report on a topic tell a story recount events or present an argument using subjective and objective language complex sentences visual features tone pace pitch and volume
Elaboration: Exploring the effects of changing tone, volume, pitch and pace in formal and informal contexts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver structured oral and/or multimodal presentations to report on a topic tell a story recount events or present an argument using subjective and objective language complex sentences visual features tone pace pitch and volume
Elaboration: Choosing a variety of appropriate words and phrases, including descriptive words and some technical vocabulary, to communicate meaning accurately

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan create rehearse and deliver structured oral and/or multimodal presentations to report on a topic tell a story recount events or present an argument using subjective and objective language complex sentences visual features tone pace pitch and volume
Elaboration: Rehearsing a presentation with a peer, and sharing feedback about tone, pace, pitch and volume appropriate to audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write words using clearly formed joined letters with developing fluency and automaticity
Elaboration: #VALUE!

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use and apply phonological and morphological knowledge to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations including a variety of vowel sounds and known prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Recognising unstressed vowels in multisyllabic words and how these vowel sounds are written; for example, "builder" and "animal"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling and practising saying words with the correct syllable stress,

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use and apply phonological and morphological knowledge to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations including a variety of vowel sounds and known prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Recognising unstressed vowels in multisyllabic words and how these vowel sounds are written; for example, "builder" and "animal"
EALDElaboration: •using syllables to support encoding during writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use and apply phonological and morphological knowledge to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations including a variety of vowel sounds and known prefixes and suffixes
Elaboration: Using phonic and morphemic knowledge to read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter combinations; for example, "straightaway" and "thoughtful"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use knowledge of letter patterns including double letters spelling generalisations morphological word families common prefixes and suffixes and word origins to spell more complex words
Elaboration: Applying generalisations for adding affixes; for example, "hope" - "hoping", "begin" - "beginning", "country" - "countries"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •segmenting and reforming words to understand how words form the basis of morphemic families; for example breaking up ‘uncaring’ ‘careful’, ‘caring’ to the base word ‘care.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to use knowledge of letter patterns including double letters spelling generalisations morphological word families common prefixes and suffixes and word origins to spell more complex words
Elaboration: Building morphemic word families and exploring word origins, for example, "tricycle", "tripod" and "triangle"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read and write high-frequency words including homophones and know how to use context to identify correct spelling
Elaboration: Recognising that contextual and syntactical clues can be used to determine the use of homophones; for example, "we grow wheat on our farm.", "the train trip will take about an hour."
